page.title: 14FERRING
page.content: Ferring is one of the numerous "ingas" settlements of the Sussex coastal plain. Original Saxon Settlement was on the outcrop of Highdown Hill to the north where a substantial pagan cemetery was found. In 765 Walhere the thane was granted 12 hides of land which are called "Ferring" by King Osmund to build a monastery. In 791 Ealdwulf dux of the south Saxons granted Bishop Withun of Selsey leave to build the church of St. Andrew at Ferring. In the 1086 Survey "Ferringes" was the demense of the Bishop of Chichester. The village subsequently developed as two smalll farming communities, east and west Ferring, the latter based around the church, the former in Sea Lane. The population remained at between 200 and 300 people for many centuries.
